awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Study of Defect Water-Interactions in Lithium Silicate Ceramics
awd_abstract_narration:
Lithium silicate ceramics are a critical component of solid state batteries and fusion reactors in the energy sector. Lithium silicate ceramics contain a number of defects in their crystal structure, which can affect how the system interacts with water, though the precise nature of the relationship is unknown. Evaluation of the mechanism by which the defects in the lithium silicate ceramics interact with water will allow for the development of longer lasting materials in batteries and fusion reactors. Based on the complex structure of the lithium silicate ceramic computational methods will be employed to provide extensive atomic level information of the structures and how they evolve with time.  The proposed research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Xiaotao Zu at the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China in Chengdu. Dr. Zu is an expert in the computational methods which will be employed to study the defect-water interactions in lithium silicate ceramics. 

First principles simulation methods will be applied to the simulation of lithium silicates to provide extensive atomistic and electronic information about the crystalline structures, including the effects of point and electronic defects on both bulk and electronic properties and in the presence of water. The identification of the mechanisms responsible for the changes in water diffusion in the region of the defects will provide insight into the role of water on any structural changes which occur in lithium silicate ceramics. The proposed work will provide a base of knowledge on lithium silicate ceramics that can then be extended to the investigation of defect structures in more complex crystalline multicomponent silicates, including the primary materials used in lithium batteries. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

por.por_cntn:
Lithium silicates are used in solid state batteries, fusion reactors, and in carbon sequestration, leading to an increased interest in the structure and properties of these ceramic materials. The development of point defects affects the reactions between the system and ambient humidity, which includes the movement of water through the system, though the details of this interaction is unknown. Understanding this process allows for the development of more stable materials for energy applications. Through collaboration with Dr. Xiaotao Zu and Dr. Haiyan Xiao at the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC) in Chengdu, China, aspects of the structure of lithium silicate ceramics after the introduction of point defects was performed through the use of computational methods.

First principle simulations were implemented for the study of the structure of lithium silicate ceramics and allow for an accurate description of the changes in atomic structure after the formation of vacancies and interstitial point defects in the crystal structure. Lithium silicate structure models were generated and interatomic distances, bond angles, and densities were found to be in good agreement with experimental results. Negatively charged lithium vacancies were identified as the lowest energy defects, as well as negatively charged silicon vacancies at high Fermi energy levels. The introduction of point defects resulted in changes in the electronic structure of the material, including variations in the band gap and the density of states. Introduction of water into the defect sites resulted in the disassociation of the molecule into oxygen and hydroxide molecules, indicating the high reactivity of the sites and their ability to alter water diffusion.

The collaboration developed during the EAPSI program between the PI and Dr. Zu and Dr. Xiao is on-going, and continues to analyze more complex point and two-dimensional defects, such as peroxide defects and surfaces, on the properties of lithium silicate ceramics. The opportunity for scientific and cultural exchange provided by the EAPSI program has allowed for a better understanding of the benefits and challenges of collaborating with scientists abroad, and provided additional technical expertise in the calculation of defect structures which will be applied to future projects on ceramic materials. It is anticipated that research projects between the PI and Dr. Zu and Dr. Xiao will continue to be developed, and that this opportunity has allowed for a greater understanding of the world-wide scientific community for the PI.
